poem:
**On the Allendale Moors**

High above the moors,  
where streams sketch their stories  
and shadows define the earth,  
a hardy bloom rises—  
color woven among stone embraces.  
The valley, green and boundless,  
etches its memory,  
all the while leaning—  
where Scotland's breath meets England's heathered whisper.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: This hardy survivor is brightening up the moors | Susie White From high on the Allendale moors, I can see right to the Scottish border and the soft blue outline of the Cheviot Hills. Below me, the West Allen Valley holds deeper colours, the land green and bounded with stone walls or dotted with small woods. Shadows thrown by the early evening light pick out every feature: streams, cleughs, barns and farms, mining spoil". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
